bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Messrs. Micajah Perry, Sr. and Jr., January 17, 1721

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to London merchants Messrs. Micajah Perry and his grandson of the same name, January 17, 1721, reporting on the recent session of the Virginia Assembly that had sat until Christmas. William Byrd, representative of the colony in England, was voted £400 but the governor attached conditions Byrd would not agree to, and they can get the details when Byrd arrives. Most of the ships presently in Virginia are from Bristol and Liverpool, and they are not expecting the London ships until March. He comments that Bristol is the worst tobacco market in Britain but he has received good prices there. The deaths of James Walker and Mrs. Rostow, and the serious illness of Cole Digges, are recorded. He concludes that he has considered what to do with his surplus cash in the Perry's hands, but will not call on it soon, and notes that there will be some protested notes from his involvement with sale of slaves from the ship, the Mercury.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Messrs. Micajah Perry, Sr. and Jr., January 17, 1721

opener.dateline:
Rappahannock, [Lancaster County, Virginia]
Jany. 17th 1720/21
Messrs. Perry
Senr. & Junr.—

div1.p:
My last was of Novr. the 8th, Our Assembly satt 
till Christmas We Just gott home to Eate our Plumb Pottage 
Eighteen Laws were past Some of them no doubt will meet 
wth. a little animadversion on Yor. Side the water. The Assembly 
has bin liberall of their money upon several accounts among 
others they voted Collo. Byrd who they appointed their Agent 
for their present affarrs  [sic]400 pound this mett wth. a Slurr the Goverr.
 
would not pass It but upon Such Conditions Byrd would 
not come into, the particulars he will best tell when he getts 
among You, The Govr. hath made no Secretary as Yett 
he Executes the place himself all our Clerks Comissions 





run in his Name so much for polliticks;mdash;

We have few Ships among us hitherto Some Bristol
Men & Some from Leverpool It seems the Londoners were
not to sail till after Christmas. We may look out for them
I reckon in March. I believe there will be no want of
Tobo. when they come wish they may be modest in their de=
=mands for freight, the Bristol Markett is the worst in England
& yett I had 10d. there for Stemd & 10½ at Leverpool,

James Walker is lately dead & so is Mrs. Roscow, Collo. Diggs
hath had a severe spell but I hear is recovering. all Yor. other
friends for what I know are well & may this find You So.
the Concluding Clause of this Lettr. from the other side.

I am not unthot.full how many ways I have had of late
to make use of my Cash in Yor. hands, but You may Expect I
Shall Trespass no further for a good while, I'm affraid
the Mercury's affair will produce me Some Considerable
protests wch. tis to be doubted will be too common a Complaint
when the Ships arrive
div1.closer: I am Gent Yor. most humble Servt.

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1720 July-1721 July, BR 227, Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens, San Marino, California. Printed: Wright. Letters of Robert Carter. . . . pp. 62-63.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and state have been added for clarity.

[1] Louis Wright wrote, "A feud of long standing existed between William Byrd and Lieutenant Governor Alexander Spotswood. Byrd, as agent for the colony, opposed Spotswood's efforts to limit the power of the Countil. For details of their quarrel, see Leonidas Dodson, Alexander Spotswood, Governor of Colonial Virginia, 1710-22 (Philadelphia, 1932), 144 ff." (Wright. Letters of Robert Carter. . . . p. 62.)

[2] James Walker (d. 1721) was a merchant in Middlesex County who, with his brother Richard, was one of the developers of Urbanna; he served as sheriff of Middlesex (Torrance. Virginia Wills and Administrations,1632-1800. p. 438.; "Answers to Queries," 1Virginia Magazine of History and Biography, 1[1893-84]:470-1; Rutman and Rutman, A Place in Time: Middlesex. . . . pp. 228-31.)
[3] "Probably the wife of James Roscow, appointed receiver-general of quitrents in 1716." (Wright. Letters of Robert Carter. . . . p. 63.)

[4] Cole Digges (1692-1744), of "Belfield," York County, came from a distinguished family. His father had been a member of the Council, and his grandfather the governor of Virginia. He was returned as a burgess from Warwick County in 1718, was appointed to the Council the next year, and held the usual offices of justice and militia commander (for Elizabeth City, Warwick, and York counties). (Morton. ed. The Present State of Virginia. . . by Hugh Jones. p. 239.)

[5] The draft of this letter ends just before the clause that begins "the Concludeing Clause. . . ." The following paragraph was originally dictated at the end of the preceding letter to the Perrys in the letter book, but Carter marked it to be copied as the concluding paragraph to this letter, and it has been placed here.

[6] Carter and Robert Tucker were the agents for the sale of slaves carried to Virginia by the Mercury which was owned by Francis Chamberlayne and Francis Sitwell. See Carter's letters to Chamberlayne and Sitwell concerning this sale of slaves on July 26, 27, and September 27, 1720, and on July 2, 1723.
